Award.AwardTitle: Structural and dynamic characterization of 2/2 hemoglobins

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit
The physical properties of globular proteins are a topic of intense investigation and practical importance. Multiple approaches have been deployed to understand the determinants of stability and plasticity of these vital biomolecules. Among the methods that are most useful, but so far much underutilized, is nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR) at high pressure. The combination of gentle perturbation and residue-level description afforded by this technique has excellent potential for exposing novel architectural principles in proteins. The proposed research will combine molecular biology, amino acid sequence analysis, and high-pressure NMR methods to explore the native state of a set of monomeric bacterial and algal hemoglobins. The work will investigate the original notion that a common internal cavity network is a crucial entity governing conformational changes concerted with ligand binding and volume dynamics. Studies will be extended to related proteins from organisms that live in high pressure environments to enhance the description of the molecular attributes of globins functioning under extreme conditions of pressure and low temperature. Because the globins of interest are enzymatic and of ancient origin, the results will pertain to multiple fields of inquiry besides protein physical chemistry, including phylogenetics, heme chemistry, and molecular evolution. These ramifications offer an opportunity for laboratory and classroom training of students with diverse interests.

Broader impact
The broader impact of the proposed research will be achieved through a combination of teaching, training, outreach, and dissemination. Research results will be incorporated in a biophysics undergraduate course in spectroscopy and in a graduate course in biophysical methods. Training will be provided to graduate and undergraduate students, including REU summer students, working directly on the project. Participation in outreach activities will include lab tours for high-school students along with research and career presentations to attract women and underrepresented groups to STEM fields. Participation in the Biophysics Research for Baltimore Teens summer program (organized by the Program in Molecular Biophysics of Johns Hopkins University) will focus on introducing selected high-school students of Baltimore City to scientific research. Dissemination will be through publications, lectures at other institutions, participation in conferences, and database depositions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Since the 1950?s, our understanding of how hemoglobin (Hb) functions in human blood has flourished with atomic-level descriptions of three-dimensional structures and sophisticated measurements of gas exchanges.  More recently, however, it has come to light that mammalian Hb is just one member of a very large family of related proteins.  The origin of this superfamily is now traced back to the last universal common ancestor, and with this realization come multiple questions of protein evolution.  In this project, the Lecomte research group focused on Hbs present, surprisingly, in cyanobacteria and unicellular green algae.  These photosynthetic organisms generate oxygen and their need for Hbs remains mysterious, likely related to primordial functions essentially extinguished in the Hbs of animals.  The goals were to elucidate the chemical properties of Hbs in model unicellular organisms, with special attention to those thriving under extreme conditions such as found in deep sea environments.  The approach was to prepare the globins, determine their three-dimensional structure, test their reactivity, and analyze their response to changing experimental conditions, including hydrostatic pressure.  The main characterization tools were nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy and electronic absorption spectroscopy in solution and X-ray diffraction in the crystalline state.

In one area of investigation, the properties of THB1, a Hb from the green alga and model organism Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, were described.  Like all hemoglobins, this protein utilizes the canonical proximal histidine to bind the heme cofactor, but surprisingly it also uses a lysine as a second ligand.  Lysine is rarely observed in that particular chemical role.  The structure of the protein in two different states was determined (Figure 1A with lysine bound and Figure 1B with cyanide bound where oxygen would normally bind) and suggested specific features that permit the unusual coordination.  These features were probed with amino acid replacements and allowed for a deciphering of the relationship between amino acid sequence and chemical reactivity.  Complementary studies led to evidence that THB1 functions as a modulator of a potent cellular messenger, nitric oxide.  In parallel to these investigations, the laboratory gained insight into the chemistry of cyanobacterial Hbs.  A mechanism was put forth for a novel modification of the heme group discovered earlier by the research group.  The modification, which stabilizes the protein, was transplanted into a different Hb to test its general utility in protein design and engineering.  Further structural and chemical information on the function of Hbs in extant unicellular organisms was obtained, and a role in reactive oxygen and nitrogen species detoxification was confirmed.  The work reinforces an original function for Hbs related to the toxicity of oxygen.

Broader Impacts: Besides the dissemination of results through publications and database depositions, the grant facilitated the development of significant human resource.  Over the course of the project, six graduate students and three undergraduate students received training in molecular biology, protein expression and purification, and biophysical and structural biology methods necessary to characterize heme proteins.  These students also acquired skills in communicating the scope of the project and the results of their work, both locally and nationally.  Three of the graduate students completed their PhD work while being supported by the grant.  One of the graduate students was from the laboratory of a collaborator based in Argentina.  Two senior scientists and a laboratory technician extended the reach of the project and the breadth of training.  Two Baltimore high-school students were mentored as interns in the laboratory.  In addition, results obtained during the course of the research were incorporated in biochemistry and spectroscopy courses for undergraduate and graduate students.  A research-based course was created to acquaint undergraduate students with real-life scientific investigation and the scientific method.
